profileText: (Grandfather of Charles Gerrit De Witt), a Delegate from New York; born in Kingston, Ulster County, N.Y., in 1727; pursued classical studies; colonel of militia; member of the colonel assembly, 1768-1776; delegate to the provisional convention, 1775; member of the Provisional Congress which approved the Declaration of Independence, 1775-1777; served on the constitutional committee in 1776, and on the committee of safety, 1777; Member of the Continental Congress, February 1784-October 1784; editor of the Ulster Sentinel for several years; member of the State assembly, 1781, 1785, and 1786; member of the committee to draft the State constitution; died in Kingston, N.Y., August 27, 1787; interment in Dutch Reformed Cemetery, Hurley, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: 1749-1780, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: A diary/account book dating from December 15, 1749 to June 12, 1780 when Charles De Witt was a manager of Livingston Manor, New York. The entries include store and mill accounts, as well as those of the Ancram Ironworks. Scattered entries after 1754 usually concerned with his activities as a farmer in Hurley, Ulster County, New York. Also included are recipes and formulas.
